<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_read_:
```c
static int lfs_dir_read_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir, struct lfs_info *info) {
    memset(info, 0, sizeof(*info));

    // special offset for '.' and '..'
    if (dir->pos == 0) {
        info->type = LFS_TYPE_DIR;
        strcpy(info->name, ".");
        dir->pos += 1;
        return true;
    } else if (dir->pos == 1) {
        info->type = LFS_TYPE_DIR;
        strcpy(info->name, "..");
        dir->pos += 1;
        return true;
    }

    while (true) {
        if (dir->id == dir->m.count) {
            if (!dir->m.split) {
                return false;
            }

            int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir->m, dir->m.tail);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }

            dir->id = 0;
        }

        int err = lfs_dir_getinfo(lfs, &dir->m, dir->id, info);
        if (err && err != LFS_ERR_NOENT) {
            return err;
        }

        dir->id += 1;
        if (err != LFS_ERR_NOENT) {
            break;
        }
    }

    dir->pos += 1;
    return true;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other controlling expressions in the function do not appear invariant and therefore do not need investigation under Rule 14.3: the checks if (dir->pos == 0) and else if (dir->pos == 1) depend on dir->pos and update it; if (dir->id == dir->m.count) depends on mutable state dir->id and dir->m.count; if (!dir->m.split) depends on object state; the checks of function return values (if (err) and if (err && err != LFS_ERR_NOENT) and later if (err != LFS_ERR_NOENT)) all depend on the results of called functions and local variable err. These are not compile-time or invariant controlling expressions. The only invariant controlling expression present is the while (true) loop, which should be examined to determine whether the use of an invariant expression is intended (e.g. an intentional infinite loop with explicit exits) and compliant with the rule's exceptions.
